text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.
No. 5
Pioneer Emigration and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: MARIA GIBSON (92000)
Present Address: BRADY, SASK.
Pioneer Address: 6 A.R., SASK.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1944

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE
This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, and answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your cooperation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questions will be answered in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? How often did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days?

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "make potluck" used, or was some other expression common?)

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Friendly cup of tea?

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one house to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, once a year?
SAHATHEM ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? How many of these were bachelor's homes?

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Twice a year?

3. Did you usually visit on Sundays, or other days? Sunday.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Without invitation.

What time of the day did you go? - In the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Morning.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Usually overnight.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) Just as it was.

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Friendly cup of tea.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"?

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, what drives or dances in homes? Describe.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at certain times - every two weeks, once a month, etc.? Yes or No.
8. Tell us what was made of the school house for community dances, bon-bons, etc., if you have not described these in the school district (questionnaire). Give dates.

9. How much of your social life was centered around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

10. What was your first community hall built? Who built it? What material was it made of? Who organized it? Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? If you lived in the country, did you contribute to the local school house for district gatherings, and close to the hall for all other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings?

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Paddy, what's the number?

12. Was there card playing for prizes? Yes. What dances were popular? Waltz, two steps, quadrille.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. How was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell me what was made of the school house for community dinner, box socials, etc., and what was used. (Include also the school Christmas tree, pianos, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built? 1924

10. What was the material used in the construction? Wood

11. Who built it? The community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.

12. Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall?

13. To what extent did it take the place of homes for the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? For example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.?
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? If so, describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and given approximate dates wherever possible. In visiting or social life became noticeable.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' Local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? Mentally.

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not until 1946.

When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
3. That attempts at formality, or "swank," do you remember in small towns, such as glances and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially in parlor, etc.?

12. Was the obituary known in your community? Yes.

13. Describe what you remember about chinwags, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?

Give the date and reason for its being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers' local in your community yet?

Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged?

How often did it meet?

What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? Not until 1946.

When was it organized?

Approximately how many women belonged to it?

Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1944, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities, its local or national purpose (who belonged (men, women, young people), whether it included people only in our relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was concerned in a broader or wider area (and if connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What names were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings? School and community hall.

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Yes

Describe, telling who gave them (local, ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)? Summer

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)? Summer
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1945, and tell me the name of each. Note when it was first organized, its activities, its location, and people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a single district), or if it covered a larger area (like a town or village) and how many communities it included (if known). (Note: Organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What names were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. What did various organizations hold their meetings? School, church, community hall, etc.

20. Were you accustomed to having General Information Lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? If so, who gave them? (Local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.) How often were they held? How well did they attend? Any other details about them?

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-numbering, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "whist," "poker," "rummy," or others, checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. Give the reasons.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICTURES AND STORES

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan?

Give year and month if possible. 1916

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as whist, pinochle, cribbage, or others; checkers or other games? 

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Did there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain. 

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, birchbark baskets, ropes or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICTURES AND SPORTS

25. What was the date of the first picture that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. 

26. Who organized it? 

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 

28. Was it the first picture held in the community? 

If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held? 

29. What were the amusements at the pictures you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? 

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller gatherings?

31. What did you have to eat and drink? 

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
32. Describe any features of this plant to which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnic, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people), organized foot ball, played by the older as well as young men.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? 1911

How long did it continue? 1919

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.) When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

Women's races, women's ball games.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

From the time the first G.A.A. 24th May picnic, speeches were in attendance, and now films, educational & amusing pictures are held also, now by the wheat pool.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

Association football, played by the older as well younger men.

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

Foot-ball.

What year? 1911

How long did it continue? 1919

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

Hockey team 1907.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.)

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for? Have heard.
7. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Why?

40. Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans? If so, what was responsible for starting the first sports day?

Then was the sports day usually held (that month, or any special day, such as May 2nd or July 1st)? Why?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? Give names, dates.

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors.) If possible, if not, tell us nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind. (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors? Occasionally.

45. Did you buy any books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes. When was it begun? 1910

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material? Certainly.
7.

40. When did an annual "Sports day" become established in your community? May 24th.

Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community games?

Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

Then was the sports day usually held? (that month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball, or other teams? (Give names, and dates.)

42. What books did you bring with you than you came away? (Give a list of the names and stories if possible.) If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind. (Use extra sheets if necessary.)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?

What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy any books after you came away? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school?

Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? Yes.

When was it begun? 1910

To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for home reading?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? 1947

Is it still in existence? Yes

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? At disbandment 1949.

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

Jim A. Gibson, on the above N.C. Elmo Co.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

Family Herald, United Kingdom, Western Union, National Home Monthly, Grain Growers Guide, Free Press, National Home Monthly, Gladys Home Journal.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you took subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain. No
8. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes.

When was it started? 1947

Is it still in existence? No

If not, when was it discontinued, and why? 1954

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contains, how many people used it, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

From a library in the town of V.C. Education.

50. That newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the ward? Family Weekly, Home Journal, National Home Monthly.

51. Name newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the ward? Family Weekly, Home Journal, National Home Monthly.

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Yes.

Give dates and tell how and where you get them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? Violin, guitar.

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? Violin, guitar.

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the house? Yodeling, old-time songs.

In the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started? How long did it continue?

Who started it? Who was bandmaster?

How many were in it? What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

This district was especially supplied with musical talent for piano, violin, and vocal, as well as entertainments.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? 

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have? 

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them. 

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your house entertainment in early years in the West? Describe. 

violin, guitar

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the house? 

in the community? 

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain. 

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain. 

63. Was there a band in your community? 

Who started it? 

How many were in it? 

What instruments were included? 

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for. 

This district was especially supplied with musical talent for piano, violins, and vocal, as well as entertainers.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIESTS AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

The raising of the (flag) flag, paid by Bratton, Eng., to the Bratton school in 1910 at which all you pupils were present.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HERBES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? If so, explain.

Give details of the collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival or leaving, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

GENERAL

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainments, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned.

(Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).

The raising of the flag at which all the pupils were present.
Oxford
